channel.title: NPR All Things Considered
channel.description: All Things Considered hosts Ailsa Chang, Mary Louise Kelly, Ari Shapiro, Juana Summers and Scott Detrow present the program's trademark mix of news, interviews, commentaries, reviews, and offbeat features 7 days a week.

item.title: Tour bus involved in rollover crash on I-90 near Pembroke, N.Y.
item.description: Authorities are calling a bus crash in upstate New York a "mass casualty" incident.

item.title: FBI searches John Bolton's home, office
item.description: The search of the home and office of former President Trump national security adviser and frequent critic John Bolton raises questions about how the administration is using law enforcement.

item.title: Gaza famine confirmed by U.N.-backed panel
item.description: It is the first time the IPC has declared a famine in the Middle East.

item.title: Mastodon guitarist and vocalist Brent Hinds dies at 51
item.description: Guitarist and vocalist Brent Hinds, who was a member of the heavy metal band Mastodon, died this week. For over two decades, Hinds and his bandmates were known within the metal scene for complex riffs and epic storytelling. The 51-year-old was involved in a motorcycle accident in Atlanta.

item.title: Famine is declared in Gaza. Will anything change?
item.description: NPR's Juana Summers speaks with Jean-Martin Bauer Director of Food Security and Nutrition at the World Food Programme about the famine declaration in Gaza.

item.title: After Supreme Court ruling on NIH funding, uncertainty remains for many scientists
item.description: On Thursday, the Supreme Court decided that, at least temporarily, the National Institute of Health does not need to continue paying hundreds of millions in grants it stopped funding.Â But the court also left in place a lower court ruling that voided NIH memos that enforced the administration's policies. The matter now plays out in the lower courts.

item.title: Texas and California advance in their reshaping of the national political landscape
item.description: President Trump initiated a redistricting arms race when he urged Texas to redraw its congressional map to boost Republicans. It's part of a broader trend of Trump pushing the limits of democracy when it comes to consolidating power.

item.title: What D.C. police data show about Trump administration's arrests in the city
item.description: The Trump administration says it has arrested more than 700 people in Washington, DC as part of its mission to crack down on crime. Data given to NPR by the city's police department indicates a ramp-up in arrests during the campaign, but criminal justice experts caution that it's difficult to draw conclusions about public safety merely from arrests.

item.title: Release of Uvalde school shooting documents raises questions for victims' families
item.description: Family members of the victims of the 2022 Uvalde school shooting where 19 students and two teachers died, recently got a look at newly released files from the Uvalde Consolidated School District and Uvalde County from the day of the shooting. More than three years after the tragedy, their suffering lingers without answers to their questions about how the security protocols failed that day.

item.title: Where does Russia's opposition stand today, with shifting U.S.-Russia relations?
item.description: Now that multiple countries are talking about negotiating an end to Russia's war in Ukraine, where does the Russian opposition movement stand today after Alexei Navalny's death in 2024?
